stem: The patient's thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is significantly elevated.  Based on this finding, the nurse should anticipate the provider will order further testing to evaluate for _____.

rationale.correct: Hypothyroidism. An elevated TSH level indicates that the thyroid gland is not producing enough thyroid hormone, leading to hypothyroidism. Further testing, such as T4 and thyroid antibody tests, is needed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

mnemonic.name: Memory aid for Hypothyroidism Symptoms
mnemonic.description: THYROID: Tiredness, Hair loss, Yawning (fatigue), Reduced metabolism (weight gain, constipation), Intolerance to cold, Obesity, Decreased heart rate

rationale.incorrect: Cushing's syndrome. Cushing's syndrome involves excess cortisol production and presents with different symptoms than those exhibited by this patient.

questionTrap.reason: Students may select hyperthyroidism if they don't understand the inverse relationship between TSH and thyroid hormone levels.
questionTrap.intervention: Review the pathophysiology of hypothyroidism and the role of TSH in regulating thyroid hormone production.

clinicalPearls: TSH is the most sensitive test for primary thyroid disease.
Hypothyroidism is more common in women and older adults.
Symptoms of hypothyroidism can be subtle and may be attributed to other conditions.

itemContext.sbar: S: Patient reports increasing fatigue, weight gain (approx. 10 lbs in 2 months), and constipation. B: Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications are lisinopril and atorvastatin. A: TSH level is elevated. Patient is alert and oriented x3, but appears lethargic. R: Recommend further evaluation of thyroid function. Consider thyroid antibody testing.
